text:
People say that
data is meaningless.
Information is free.

It's what you're able to do
with that data that matters.

I did not code at all up
until about six months ago,

even though I came
from the tech industry.

Code club became this
great motivator for me

to learn on my own, to
develop this new skill that's

really becoming the
new business literacy.

Code club is just a
collection of Harvard MBAs who

love technology and interested
in either maintaining

technical skills
or acquiring them.

That inner logic
for our program--

We don't think that we're going
to turn people into expert
programmers in a semester.

Instead, our idea was we
want to empower people

with the confidence
and the skills

to go out and figure out how to
build anything that they want

to build, which is really
the fundamental of computer
science.

Right now, we're teaching the
students fundamental Python

to understand basically how
to look at data and access
and utilize that data.

As we move forward,
we want the students

to gain more confidence,
thinking, what's a problem?

What kind of data do I
have on that problem?

How can I use the
program language

I have to turn that
data into a solution?

Otherwise, you're kind of
stuck in this sea of noise,

and you're not quite
sure what to grasp at.

But knowing all this
noise relates to itself

and how really it's organized
in a very beautiful way,

that's what connects the
dots between a sea of data,

a sea of numbers, and a very
actionable, tangible insight

and solution that you can
then bring to your business.

For our generation, computers
permeate every aspect
of business.

Being able to speak the
language and communicate

both with business individuals
as well as engineers

will separate those who are most
successful in entrepreneurship
and innovation.

It really makes my day when
I can see students struggling

with concepts that we're trying
to teach them, but then learn
it and get excited about that.

The beautiful thing about
learning programming
is that you can start out small.

And very quickly, you'll
be surprised to see

how you can build on
your initial learnings

and how you can make amazing
things happen that you never
thought possible.
